segments.text: Morning after the storm. The wind stopped around 3 AM and I actually slept pretty well after that.
Let me unzip the vestibule and see what we're dealing with... wow. About 30 centimeters of fresh snow.
The tent performed perfectly. No tears, no bent poles, everything held. This thing's earned my trust.
The landscape looks completely transformed. Everything's blanketed in white. Pristine, untouched snow everywhere.
I need to brush the snow off the tent before it melts and refreezes. And dig out my gear that was outside.
The bear canister is buried. Let me find where I left it... there it is, under about half a meter of snow.
This changes my plans for today. The trail to the higher peaks will be slow going with this much fresh snow.
But avalanche risk is definitely elevated now. I should stick to lower elevations and gentler slopes.
Safety first. No summit is worth dying for. Maybe I'll do a shorter loop hike, let the snowpack stabilize.
The sky's clear now. Blue and bright. Hard to believe there was a storm last night.
Let me get the stove going for coffee and oatmeal. Then I'll check my gear and make a proper plan for the day.
I'm honestly proud of how I handled last night. Stayed calm, stayed safe, trusted my preparation.
This trip has been exactly what I needed. Testing myself, finding that I'm stronger than I thought.

environment.background_sounds: quiet morning, snow crunching, birds starting to call
